items.name: General Info.
items.subcontent:
The maps here can be used to answer questions such as ...
  • “Is this property in the floodplain?”
  • “What is the zoning for this parcel?”
  • “What is the area of this parcel or these two parcels combined?”

items.name: Navigation
items.content:
1. Drag to pan
  2. SHIFT + Click to recenter
  3. SHIFT + Drag to zoom in
  4. SHIFT + CTRL + Drag to zoom out
  5. Mouse scroll up to zoom in
  6. Mouse scroll down to zoom out
  7. Use Arrow keys to pan
  8. + key to zoom in one level
  9. - key to zoom out one level
  10. Double Click to Center and Zoom in

items.name: About GC Webmaps
items.subheader: System Requirements and How the maps are made
items.content: Most of the maps here are made using javascript and the ArcGIS javascript API. One implication of that is that they require that javascript be enabled in your web browser. There are two basic types of data displayed in the maps (basemaps and data services). The basemap is underneath the other data showing background reference information which can be imagery, roads, or topography (among other possibilities). The data services included are made from GIS data acquired by the County and turned into services using ArcGIS Server (ESRI Inc.). ArcGIS Server converts the gis data into a format that can be read by the web browser. The ArcGIS javascript API provides a model for writing javascript code to make requests or “queries” from these data services or “REST” services to display data in different ways and basically interact with the map.

items.name: Layers
items.header: Layers in the Planning and Zoning Map

items.name: Critical Facilities
items.subcontent: Critical Facilities is a point layer of Parks, Community Buildings, Libraries, Schools, Government Buildings (i.e. Post Offices), Roads and Utilities Facilities, Airports, Nursing Homes, Communications Towers, and Fire & Rescue Stations.

items.name: Gas Wells
items.subcontent: Gas Wells is a point layer representing Natural Gas Wells in the County.
